commentBody:
From the column:

46A. This was a tough one. Note the possessives in the clue: [Macy’s or Wendy’s, for instance?] is not referring to a department store and a restaurant chain.
___

No incorrect information there, but there's no causal connection.  The apostrophes do not mean that you should think of something other than the two businesses; if the answer did have to do with your local Macy's and your local Wendy's, the apostrophe would still be there.  Although Macy's often stylizes that apostrophe with a  five-pointed star.

It's just misdirection.
Wrong puzzle answers  posted , from 2018
Link to solved puzzle is wrong. Takes you to a puzzle from 2018.
Until the link is corrected, you can see the answer key here: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/15/2024

Interesting puzzle.  

Usually, I look to easy short fill 
to set me up for the longer entries.  

Today, the longer entries came easier 
than most of the crossing fill.

I'll take the BLINI with [caviar].

I finished this one surprisingly quickly considering that I was watching the Eagles - Commanders game while doing it.  Puzzles like this one, with lots of multi-word phrases, are not my favorites, especially if the phrases are relatively vanilla.  However, I did like seeing the word SOUPÇONS pop up.

It was nice to see ERMA Franklin get a shout out.  Toiling her whole career in the shadow of sister Aretha she’s largely overlooked, but was a fine singer in her own right.  Adding insult to injury, her best performance, Piece Of My Heart, was overshadowed by Janis Joplin’s powerful cover.

Like a typical Friday, the first pass fills in very little, but things slowly fall into place. I finished within seconds of my Friday average. It seems like 25D / 34A is the epitome of a Natick: a crossing two unfamiliar proper names. And 45A will always remind me of Mamet... it's on Netflix for a couple more weeks. Clip NSFW! https://youtube.com/shorts/wn5yyGOZSww?si=Tq4GExbTmgqPOLf_
Nice smooth puzzle, once I let go of the idea that people might put caviar on a scoNe.
“Automagically” (from the Constructor Notes) is my new favorite word. Thank you!
As an algebraist, I was thrilled to see IDEMPOTENT  in today’s puzzle! Also enjoyed the other lively entries. A quick solve for a Friday, but very enjoyable!

Little-known secondary meaning of IDEMPOTENT:

Unused for decades, yet still available for instant recall when required in a crossword puzzle.

"The Internet, ...EVERHEARDOFIT?" This was my favorite clue and answer, because it's an expression that is easy and obvious to use, but hard to eloquently define. I'm often trying to explain phrases like this to my friend who is trying to master English. "Facetious question after mentioning something well known," is such a clean, concise, and perfect description. Love it. Excellent Friday.

Weirdly, the French was the easy part, and my French is for the OISEAU.  I was RARINGTOGO, but the proper names? I had nEVERHEARDOF most of them.  I asked my husband about the Cornell research institute.  He said, "Oh, Cornell. That's CARLSAGAN."  Of course I had heard of Carl Sagan, but forgot about Cornell. He swears he could never work a crossword—even so, he's always there when I'm UPINTHEAIR (but I wasn't about that one, once I let go of "committed to."

I'm not sure why this puzzle seemed so challenging. The answers seemed quite simple—once I got them.  It was the getting that was the problem.

Thank you, Alina Abidi!  I enjoyed this one immensely, and I totally get it about the subway ride.  Years ago, when I had a story published in a "little magazine" and my name was on the cover, I felt exactly the same way.

This gets a big thumbs down from me. Felt like I was breezing through it, 16 minutes with a few squares to go in the SW corner. Another 5 minutes before I had to click Check Puzzle. Using such obtuse cluing for EVICTS crossed with a French word I've never heard of (and I'm very well versed in most French culinary terms), along with two proper nouns, bad news

I didn't have to wrestle with this Friday puzzle, which possibly means that many will have found it straightforward.

Is it bad that I would prefer to stoke my own EGO and think I was on the constructor's wavelength? I hope not. 

Whatever the case may be, I had an enjoyable time, which I like to think is ultimately what really matters.

Thank you, Ms. Abidi!

My delight in the sparky long entries was overcome by distress at the trivia. Too many non-celebrity actors and singers. One trip to Google to finish the puzzle is tolerable, this one took five. 
By contrast, OISEAUX I knew right away.

I might buy a helium balloon. It's up in the air.

(What's the burst that could happen?)

Mon Dieu! C’était beaucoup de Français! (No complaints.)

And here I thought my husband made up the word “automagically”. Hmm.  Guess I’ll have to sit in on some of his programmer meetings to see what other cleverness I am mistakenly crediting to him. (On the other hand… programmer meetings? Nah. I’m good.)

Too many names.

And

Names should NOT cross with names.

Names  of people I haven't heard of, Mara, Erma, Swisher.  Otherwise an easyish puzzle for a Friday. I had "got to go" instead of "gotta go" until   the very end. I did know Carl Sagan and got the Cornell connection.

Good one. Some of the longer entries have a similar in-your-face, faintly antagonistic tone that might be the result of Ms. Abidi's recent move to New York:

I can see you / Ever heard of it? / You're not wrong / Don't tell me  

-- the sort of tete-a-tetes New Yorkers enjoy with a bit of mano a mano.

According to xwordinfo, before going to the Big Apple, Abidi worked here in Pittsburgh at Duolingo, a language-training software company based here that is very successful, especially, I understand, in helping people become proficient in French, which may explain the presence of tete-a-tetes, oiseau, tres, genre, soupcons, ogre, and (with a bit of stretching) the expatriates associated with Paris, Anais NIN and GERTRUDE Stein (who was as fluent in French as in English) along with native Francoise SAGAN, whose "Bonjour Tristesse" is smashing. Ever heard of it?

Maybe I have to move to New York, too, get a thicker skin: EARLY VOTER actually made me REACT. Why, oh why did he have to RERUN?
I spent decades in computer programming and never heard "evicts" in reference to a cache. Funny the things you learn doing crosswords.

I love a snarky puzzle I can relate to 

Oh it's a little thing called __, EVERHEARDOFIT? You can just hear the sarcasm 

I love how the clue for Donna TARTT referenced The Secret History, my all time favorite book (which has yet to be made into a movie) and not The Goldfinch (which was made into a big movie).

All true puzzlers can relate to having said "I can figure it out!" DONTTELLME!
I enjoyed the puzzle as it unfolded and the constructor’s comments are delightful! I hope she enjoys her subway riding and finds lots of solvers to surprise.
I agree with you. I have crocheted for 50 years. I’ve even made lace once. It is NOT an intermediate skill. It’s really advanced and hard.
One of those lovely puzzles you just work on steadily and it all comes together in one session ... just under 26 mins. Perfect for a Friday, and a great way to start the weekend!

Cache eviction and idempotency in the same puzzle?  Nice.  It almost makes up for "teraflop" (different constructor) from a while back.

Remember: there are only two difficult problems in computer science: naming things, knowing when to clear the cache, and fencepost errors.

As an avid thrower it's always nice to see yoyo in the grid too!

I've studied math and never heard of an "Idempotent." Wouldn't that only apply to 0 and 1?

A bit of a tough puzzle for me with all the French, but I managed.

Ugh. Nasty puzzle today. So much name trivia.

And the answer key I get is from 2018.
Editors - The answer key link goes to a puzzle from 2018.

I was zipping through this until I crashed to a stop in the SW.  The crossing of OISEAU and CLOSER, and CLOSER crossing CLIP was giving me fits.  Even after I settled on CLOSER (with slightly less than 100% confidence), I couldn't justify CLIP for about 2 long minutes.  I kept thinking something else was wrong and re-checked my other answers until it finally hit me.  So obvious, yet my brain could not see it.

Just a few words of praise for the Customer Care Team, the folks (mentioned atop this comments column) who to contact if you're having a technical or other issue regarding the NYT puzzles.

Twice now they've restored my streak, when for good reason I couldn't solve the puzzle digitally on the app for a period of days (but solved it in another way).  Not only did they restore the streak, but they were kind and personable in our conversations.

It's a good group.

Tough one for me and had to cheat a bit to get through it, but some nice 'aha' moments when I finally had enough crosses to work something out. And then... with apologies, this is completely off-topic but something that dawned on me this morning. A movie scene that seems just incredibly appropriate at this moment in time in this country. Let's not give up. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HM-E2H1ChJM We'll be back. ..
I thought the long answers were great, but too many Naticks for me, and I didn't care for the 45D clue.

YES.

Was RARING TO GO.
C’mon Friday puzzle!
Let’s get INTO it!

WILD RIDE!

Fast and furious, this one.

Every thing or name I hasn’t HEARD OF
 -and it was BRIMming with things and
names I didn’t know -
were TIPped off by the crosses
with their HINTs 
and wait…
DONT TELL ME…

Aha! INSIGHT!
I have an IDEA!

The fun did not LET UP.

Alina, 
I CAN SEE YOU having your
subway ride of glory, and good for you!
YOURE NOT WRONG, so dive into it!

Thanks for a fun solve!

Happy Friday all! 
Hope the weekend is a lovely one.
I’m still not sure I understand 45 down.  Does it have to do with CLIPpers being used to cut hairs?

The clue for idempotent doesn’t seem to be correct.   I didn’t know the word and looked it up.  All the definitions say it refers to a function operating on the result of the same function.  For example abs(abs(x)) means taking the absolute value of an absolute value.  It is always the same as just taking the absolute value once so the absolute value function is idempotent.  The puzzle definition refers to multiplication which is not at all the same.  And multplying a number by itself usually doesn't give the number.

This puzzle is terrible. Friday's are usually my favorite. I don't appreciate all of these French terms intersecting with random names and words like idempotent. No one uses the word evict in programming BTW. Do I need to become fluent in other languages to solve these now? Certain other sections were too easy.
An unbalanced slog.

*No spoilers before View All Replies, please*

Strands #257
“Dress for lunch”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

I love Friday mornings, but all the puzzles are done
and over already.

Not a complaint or humble-brag, you guys 
got the same puzzles, so you know.
Just a breezy morning!

Enjoyed them all. Like finishing 
the last chapter of a beautiful book…

Archives it is!

Not my favorite type of puzzle, with 7 random phrases and 10 proper names. The phrases were gettable with crosses, but if I didn't know the name and got stuck on crosses I had to look it up. 

I did enjoy the variety of interesting trivia in the clues though.  :)
Uh, I wasn't looking or anything but the "take a peek" link goes to an old puzzle from 2018
This felt like two puzzles: most of it (easy, fun), and then two or three squares that took some floating and flirting.
The answer key does not match the puzzle.  Just a few years off.  I love you, anyway.

How is TIP amount often added? I was alternating between TSP and TAD which makes more sense, while thinking I got the french clues wrong (which I actually had all right in my first attempt). It was a terrible ending for me as it devolved into a brute force game where I eventually had to look up the answer key.

The conversational phrases were my favorite part of the puzzle.  They made it feel comfy.  And, it turns out, they gave it pop, as four of them – EVER HEARD OF IT, I CAN SEE YOU, I’VE GOTTA GO, and YOU’RE NOT WRONG, have never appeared in the NYT crossword before.  It’s sweet when just one chatty debut appears in a grid, but four?  Alina has a talent for this.

A pair of happy PINGs were triggered by answers.  
•	When I filled in ICE BOX, I instantly flashed on my great-grandma Ethel, who never said “refrigerator”; it was always ICEBOX.  I adored Grandma Ethel, so my heart melted when this answer showed up.  
•	IDEMPOTENT drew out another mathy word that has slumbered in my memory for decades – “asymptote” – a word that made me smile when I met it in high school because it looked and sounded cool, and it made me smile again today.  

Lovely PuzzPair© in OISEAU and UP IN THE AIR.  I also liked seeing the mini-word-ladder of LACE / LUCE / LUTE.

So, coziness, warmth and pleasure abounded in the box today, and I’m filled with gratitude for this puzzle of yours, Alina.  Thank you!
I found this one quick and easy for a Friday.  It was almost my second Friday solve without look-ups, but I had Erla crossed with Lara, which brought me down.

My favorite type of puzzle, full of what I call "long conversational phrases," and Deb calls "vocalizations," But, Deb, your comment on WHY I like them is beautiful! RERUN night here in Detroit: Here's how Fred and Ginger walk their dogs: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcBK5pqsijI For anyone unfamiliar with 1A: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwnmr18o214 (Sorry about the bad English over-dubbing, but even a 1'11" clip from one of my favorite movies has cause me to tear up.) (2nd attempt to post--Les émeus ont beaucoup de faim aujourd'hui.)

The fill seemed quite eclectic, though none of the long phrases really resonated with me. As a mathematician, IDEMPOTENT was a gimme, though fun to see. Was reminded again how different OISEAU is from its Spanish equivalent. Didn't seem particularly difficult for a Friday puzzle, though I never felt like I was in sync with this one.

Atypically, I read through and answered some comments before posting this one, and it helped me decide. There is a lot not to like in this puzzle.  It relies heavily on niche knowledge, more so than is customary.  Most all of it was fine for me as a techie, but I still had only passing familiarity with "evict" for items aging out of a cache, had never ever heard of the long and prominently placed and almost inarguably obscure idempotent, "one might be floated or flirted with" REALLY needs a comma after floated, tres isn't (very) good, while she's been around forever I'd think many people still haven't heard of Kara Swisher, lace isn't a sophomore skill, and Shakespeare's original 1597 quarto uses "A pox o' both your houses!" TWICE.

It seems better editing was called for.  But not the worst puzzle I've seen here.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Seems like one either uses more informal ("I gotta go") or less informal ("I've got to go"). The blending of the two had me misdirected for a while, especially since the latter also fit the grid.

In much the same way that I enjoy stretching my mind towards languages I do not speak, or cultures I am only vaguely aware of, as a man I enjoy the OPI and ESSIE fills. As an ex mathematician, I had a huge easy down word in this grid, and it was a big help, but still enough fiddly corners to find challenges in. Very fun.

A pleasant challenge. Thank you Alina.

Kept trying to fit Jonas Salk instead of CARL SAGAN because I am not very smart.

I often encourage a certain someone not to sleep with a top on sooooo CAMI was not appreciated: Oink!
A few too many people's names today for my taste, alas. Not a bad puzzle but not one I enjoyed for that reason.

Really enjoyed the clues for some of the longer answers, but there were a few too many proper names for my preference. 
Had a good time with this one nonetheless!

This was fun for me because I got farther with it than most Friday's. 

Agreed, LACE is very advanced crochet.

Such a kind Friday puzzle for a week that has been anything but that.

Thank you for the respite, Alina Abidi!
I'm a software engineer too, and "automagically" fills me with rage whenever I hear it lol.
LOVE your Jalali calendar clue! Had to research it and now I know something about Nizam Al-Mulk I didn’t know before!

I can hear the screams from here.  (French vocabulary! Writers and titles!)  And who will be first to say that NObody goes to the library anymore, especially not TEENS.  (Well, maybe tots, for Story Time.)

Better clue for 55A:  "Wait! Wait!..._____ "  
Alternative clue for 56A:  Pooh's origin

New (useless) word:  IDEMPOTENT
I suspect this was the entire inspiration for the puzzle.

What?  You've never called it "the ICEBOX?"

Anybody know of a puzzle site where the creators promise not to use resources beyond their own brains to create their puzzles --i.e. where one can go tête-à-tête with the puzzle/creator and not the solver vs the entire internet?

This was a toughie but I got there despite never hearing of soupçons or idempotent . Anyone else think it should be CHOMPING at the bit instead of CHAMPING ? Apparently both phrases mean the same thing- I checked after I got the gold star . 
Feeling good about finishing this under 25 minutes . Whew .

My take on proper names.

The problem, as ever, is not that there are too many (or too few), it's a case of what one knows and what one doesn't.

So, from my perspective, today:

CARL SAGAN:  too easy for a Friday

Kara SWISHER:  too obscure, any day of the week (Thank God for crosses)

MARA Rooney:  Just Right!!  (She was in that "Tattoo" movie, wasn't she?)

Of course, this is purely *my* take on things today, but I'm curious if others agree.

Thought this was appropriately tough for a Friday, but was surprised to see I’d hit a new personal best when the bell rang! 15 minutes. Others will surely scoff that this is what qualifies as a Friday record, but I’m feeling good.

OISEAU:  often my passable Spanish can help with French answers; "birds" is a common and useful enough word; and with all its vowels, you'd think this would be an answer you'd get to know as a crossword vet.  But I don't recall ever seeing it.

I guess this knowledge gap dovetails (ahem) with me learning from an NYT crossword, earlier this year, that the doomed ALUOETTE (TRES vowels!) of song is not what I thought--the name of a pet chicken--but worse: a lark.

I did pick up from somewhere that the French describe confused people like me as a "chicken who found a knife" but, of course, I don't know how to say it in French.
The answer key links to a puzzle from 2018

Career in computer programming going back to FORTRAN and COBOL and on to Java and PYTHON and EVICT for expiring an entry in a queue was new for me. Live and learn.

Fun puzzle easier than some Fridays, lots of tasty clever  (Sneaky) clueing. Enjoyed it.

Came to gripe about "gotta" vs "got to". Had to fly-speck for it, but clearly...what the heck would a "comi" be?
I just generally don't care for gotta or gonna in written form, although they definitely escape my lips from time to time. Rant over!

Not fun. I had the distinct feeling that the constructor was looking down her nose at me. No, I have not seen "Women Talking," or "MEN." Never heard of either, in fact. I did see "Captain Marvel," but not "Ms Marvel." I don't read tech blogs, or speak French. Mightily relieved when CARL SAGAN emerged from crosses. WASABI "served with rolls" tickled my fancy though.

Cheryl Strayed? You can say that again.

A lot of chatter about personal names today. In general, I know about 40% of the celebrity names referenced in the puzzle, and today's was no different. I didn't know Mara Rooney, and was ashamed as a Detroiter I didn't immediately get Erma Franklin (Aretha's sister)--but what other letter than "M" could it be? (Sorry, all you Erlas and Ertas out there.)

In the tangle in the SE--I knew Carl Sagan, but not in context; Kara Swisher sounded vaguely familiar, but I couldn't have told you what she was known for; Donna Tartt is a name I've seen on bookstore shelves, but I couldn't tell you what she wrote (wasn't there a book called "the Sparrow"?); and Iman Vellani was completely unknown. But somehow, I managed to figure them out. So, no excuse!

In other words, it's not who you know . . .

Too many names; too many green-paint-y phrases.  And I agree with Rex that the completely baffling IDEMPOTENT was the word of the day.  It cost me my 1-letter DNF -- which is entirely my fault because my TETE had an idee fixe that it couldn't shake.

I had written in IDEOPATHIC, which was the only word I could think of that fit with the letters I had.  Soon, other crosses forced me to change to IDEoPOTENT which seemed more than possible.  

But what on earth are GERoS for the "cooties"?  Cooties to me mean LICE and it wasn't lice.  Why didn't I immediately think of GERMS?  Dunno -- just didn't.

I read WILD and I didn't read the TARTT book (which failed the "Literary Guild shelf test" when I leafed through it at a bookstore.)  But I think it won something or other and I remembered her name.  Knew CARL SAGAN, if not as clued; GERTRUDE; and sort of knew MARA and SWISHER.  So I was ahead of the game on the names today even if I didn't know IMAN and ERMA and MEN.

Big surprises:
There's a "snooze" folder?
"A POX on both your houses" is a misquote??
LACE isn't that hard to crochet?

Oh, well.  IDEMPOTENT got me good.  On to tomorrow.
I flew through this puzzle in less than Wednesday average time. Four years of high school French (many decades ago) finally paid off.
I LOVED this puzzle - felt like I was having a conversation with the constructor. I hope Ms Abidi has fun riding the subway today!
As a programmer in my mid-30s, I’m wondering if any older programmers have heard the term EVICTS used for memory. I definitely have not!
Not that I was gonna use it 👀 but the answer key linked in this column is mislinked to a key from August 2018.
This was a complete delight for me. Sometimes I'm just on the same wavelength as the constructor and this was one of those days! Thanks, Alina.

Half the time people complain when a US-based puzzle is too US-centric. Now someone experiments with the use of a first-month-of-class French noun and everyone loses their minds. There’s no pleasing this comment section at all. Cheers to anyone trying to make a crossword puzzle these days.

I actually found this one to be fairly smooth for a Friday. Finished just shy of two-thirds of my Friday average time. Yes, there were a number of clues I had no idea about but I was able to solve them by the crossing fills and intuition. I will say that I winced at 27D… “One mailing it in” for EARLY VOTER since, well, you know…
Terrible puzzle. Way too much French.

I loved this puzzle! My view of crossword puzzles: everyone has a different wheelhouse. When a puzzle contains a bunch of things I don't know, I try to learn those things. Sometimes I have to look a thing up (and learn even more about it) to solve the puzzle. This is all good. The point of Friday and Saturday puzzles is to challenge solvers, even long-time solvers.

So thank you, Alina Abidi, for teaching us a few things from your wheelhouse!
Wrong solution.
Loved this crossword!!! What a treat for my morning!

I am also an avid intermediate/advanced crocheter (I'm just short of writing my own patterns) and I had no idea what 2D was.

I suppose lace would not be considered a beginner's project, but beyond that, it really depends for on the format of the pattern, rather than the pattern itself. 

Take a complicated bit of lace, or amigurumi for example. Trying to create those from using a chart would be quite difficult, and would probably put those projects into the "advanced" category. 

But, take the same projects with nicely written patterns, include a couple of photos: that's intermediate. Take the same patterns, write them neatly, include a photo with every step, and add a video? That's something an advanced beginner can handle.

Anyway, I agree with the user who said too much French, I thought the US was a Spanish speaking country! /s

I enjoyed getting the long expressions gradually.  I also like French entries.  I also don’t mind a few look ups;  I’m not cheating anyone.  

This seemed just right for a Friday, nice one Alina.

Two random additions:

1. Yet another shortcoming of this forum software is that "pulling down" / scrolling up will conveniently refresh the comment list - AND simultaneously wipe OUT any draft posts or replies you had been laboriously composing - even if you were simply trying to scroll back up to see something.

2. That dog photo is freaking adorable.  :)

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

IDEMPOTENT is such a good word. 

A crossword full of tech, math/science, and female authors is about as "in my wheelhouse" as it gets. So much fun to feel like I'm breezing through a Friday, and so many great entries! 

Thanks Alina, this was my favorite puzzle I've done in a long time!
I know there are more important things going on in the world and with the NYT Tech Guild at the moment, but I really miss getting the Easy Mode newsletter on Friday mornings :(

A fun puzzle that wasn't that difficult for a Friday. I filled it in quickly, half the time of a typical Friday puzzle. I only had trouble with the names of personalties that I have rarely encountered, if at all. 25D, 34A, 39D, 42D. Fortunately the cross-fill took care of two names, the other two that crossed each other were a guessing game.
re. obsolete tv terms. Does any one else remember ‘give it time to warm up’?

Blows my mind that the constructor referred to this as themeless. The theme is clearly twee French girly's favorite authors. 

Not my style. Sorry, genre.
Wrong solution, please upload correct solution.  Thank you,
Phew, people's names, foreign languages, and the usual longer themeless phrases - tricky, but I got there in the end. A good challenge for the end of the week.

Too many names crossing with other names. Also why put a misquote if it isn't true? 

24D finally gave my math degree some use though! 

Fun and funky friday.
TIL about IDEMPOTENTS and cache clearing EVICTS.  Very cool and a nice lively puzzle.
I went to the answer key to check the correct spelling.  The answers are from Wednesday, November 15 2018!!!
Mon émeu est très emu. Merci beaucoup.

Answer key seems to be in French today. 

Anyone have the English link?



;)
The clue for 19A reads [A24 horror film in which...]. What does the "A24" mean in this context? A film format? The year? Or is it just a display error?
People seem interested in complaining that the answer key is incorrect than in seeing the correct answer key. Puzzling. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/15/2024
Not easy but I finished it (and when I do, it’s always without cheating). I knew something had to be wrong. Finally, I changed my answer for cooties to germs from girls, and it all fell into place.
I was stuck with TAD and DING, not having ever watched Ms. Marvel. How should I know their name is IMAN and not AMAN?
The NYT's aim is to force us all to subscribe to all of the streaming services if we want to get clues like the name of the actress who plays Mrs. Maisel.  (N)ever heard of her.
@nytimes the answer key links to Aug 15 2008

My third comment from much earlier this morning never posted but perhaps I just failed to hit the submit button.  Quite smooth other than the French and Math lessons, both TIL's.  Well done and thanks.  

Oh,  Has anyone mentioned that link to the answer key in the column connects to a time machine??   :)
"Answer keys? We don't need no stinkin' answer keys!"
Putting Donna and Kara side by side was diabolical
Terrible puzzle. I've been working with computers since the 1980s and never heard of cache evicts or eviction. Ludicrous clues and answers.

My favorite type of puzzle, full of what I call "long conversational phrases," and Deb calls "vocalizations." But your comment, Deb, on *why* I like them is beautiful! RERUN night here in Detroit: Here's how Fred and Ginger walk *their* dogs: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcBK5pqsijI For anyone unfamiliar with 1A, here's a little food porn: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwnmr18o214 (Sorry for the bad English over-dubbing; but even a 1'11" clip of one of my favorite movies has caused me to tear up.)
Dreadful puzzle. Just a mess of proper nouns and naticks. What lazy construction.
We get it, you know French…

I really enjoyed this puzzle, and I enjoyed the Constructor Notes nearly as much. I am putting Alina Abidi on my list of favorite constructors. I too loved what Deb called vocalizations. And there was some tough fill (such as IDEMPOTENT, which made perfect sense once I saw it appear), but I eventually figured them all out from crosses and good guesses. I enjoyed all the great misdirects, like the one for WASABI, and the one for CLIP, which was my last bit of fill to get the gold star. And Deb, I’m with you on the LACE clue. It took me quite some time to get it because I used to crochet but never tried lace, which does seem too hard. Thanks Alina, for a terrific puzzle that brightened my day and helped me forget things that worry me.

From today's Easy Mode newsletter (which is worth signing up for even if you'll never use the Easy Mode clues):
_______________________
Obscure proper names?
By Christina Iverson

“Why do you allow so many obscure proper names? For me, it detracts from the solving experience because it is completely random. I have no problem with popular slang, even if I don’t use it.” — Steve Immelt

From Christina:

Deciding what’s “obscure” is a tricky dilemma that editors deal with. What’s obscure to one person isn’t necessarily that to another. As the saying goes, one person’s trash crossword entry is another’s most treasured entry (or something like that).

When we review puzzles, the editors spend a lot of time discussing names and whether a person or place is something solvers should know. We often ask ourselves: Even if we don’t have the answer, do we think, oh, that was cool to learn, or who cares when we find it?

Obscure proper names?
By Christina Iverson

“Why do you allow so many obscure proper names? For me, it detracts from the solving experience because it is completely random. I have no problem with popular slang, even if I don’t use it.” — Steve Immelt

From Christina:

[see my previous comment]

A small European town with the population of 2,000 is probably a “who cares,” unless there’s a significant historical event that took place there. The name of an author who won a Pulitzer could be in a puzzle, even if the editors weren’t familiar with it. Similarly, an actor who has been a minor character in five movies doesn’t feel especially important, but someone like AYO EDEBIRI, who had a major breakout role in “The Bear,” feels worth including in a grid. When we allow names that seem on the difficult side, we generally try to make the crossing entries fair.

Why do we allow proper names at all? If we limited grids to just words, there are far fewer possible entries to use, and grids would start to feel the same. Allowing constructors to highlight people or places makes puzzles feel more colorful and full of character. They can put references in the grid that reflect their tastes and people or places they care about.

@Bunny No, the imaginary number i is not an idempotent. The definition is: x is an idempotent if and only if x^2 = x. So the only complex numbers that are idempotents under the usual multiplication operation are 0 and 1. 

Mathematicians study lots of other sets with other operations and we generally use the same notation as we do for ordinary addition and multiplication of numbers. In many of those other sets there are more numerous and more interesting idempotents. (Although I would say that 0 and 1 are mighty interesting numbers.)
@Shane It is often referred to matrices and linear operators. For example, a projection matrix is idempotent.
